_header: This worthy limiter this noble Friar
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, the Friar’s Prologue of the Canterbury Tales — 36 lines in rhyming couplets.

BodArcSelB14.First Lines:
This noble lymytour this worthi ffrerehe made alway a lovrynge
                    chere…
BodArcSelB14.Last Lines:
…and afterwarde he seide vn to the ffreretelle forth your tale
                    my leve maister dere
BodArcSelB14.Attributed Title:
…And / next folwith the ffreris prolog of the Sompnour (f. 100); the
                    ffrere (RT); Here endith the ffrere his prolog… (f.
                    100v)

BodBar20.First Lines:
This worthi lymitour þis noble ffrereHe made alwey lowryng
                    chere…
BodBar20.Last Lines:
…And aftirward he said vnto þe frereTelle forth ȝour
                    tale my leue maister dere
BodBar20.Attributed Title:
…And here / by gynnyth þe prologe of the ffrere (f.
                        120v); he endith þe prologe… (f.
                    120v)

Bod414.First Lines:
[T]his wurthy limitour this noble frereHe made alwey a noble
                    chere…
Bod414.Last Lines:
…And aftir this he seid vnto the frereTell furth your tale
                    leue maister dere
Bod414.Attributed Title: Here begynneth the prolog of the ffrere (f. 78v)

Bod686.Attributed Title:
Here begynneth þe prologe of þe freris tale (f. 86); Here endeth

CULIi326.First Lines:
This noble lymytoure this worthy ffrereVppon the sompnore but for

                    saide vnto the ffrere
CULIi326.Attributed Title:

                    Prologe (RT); Here Endeth the ffrerers prologe
